text: The effect of heat shock on the expression of the nuclear protooncogenes <extra_id_0> c-fos <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> c-jun <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and <extra_id_0> c-myc <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was studied in human lymphoid cells .

text: Heat shock caused an increase in <extra_id_0> c-fos <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> c-jun <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA levels and a decrease in <extra_id_0> c-myc <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA levels in pre-B ( Hyon ) and T ( DND-41 ) cell lines as well as in freshly isolated normal human thymocytes .

text: The changes in the mRNA levels of these protooncogenes in Hyon cells were most pronounced at 42 and 43 degrees C ; kinetic analysis demonstrated that the changes could be detected within 30 min of heat shock .
Altered transcription of <extra_id_0> c-fos <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> c-myc <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> genes was the primary effect of heat shock .

text: Secondarily , heat shock of Hyon cells stabilized the <extra_id_0> c-myc <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA level by increasing its half-life from 24 to 45 min .
The overall effect of heat shock on <extra_id_0> c-myc <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA level , however , was a marked inhibition of its transcription .

text: These results demonstrate that the transcription of nuclear protooncogenes is regulated by heat shock indicating a role for nuclear protooncogenes in the stress response of lymphoid cells .
